definition.name: Gladiator
definition.description:
A gladiator is as much an entertainer as any minstrel or circus performer, trained to make the arts of combat into a spectacle the crowd can enjoy. This kind of flashy combat is your entertainer routine, though you might also have some skills as a tumbler or actor.

 

Skill Proficiencies: Acrobatics, Performance
Tool Proficiencies: Disguise kit, one type of musical instrument
Equipment: An inexpensive but unusual weapon or a musical instrument (one of your choice), the favor of an admirer (love letter, lock of hair, or trinket), a costume, and a pouch containing 15 gp

 
 
 

FEATURE: BY POPULAR DEMAND

You can always find a place to perform in any place that features combat for entertainment — perhaps a gladiatorial arena or secret pit fighting club. At such a place, you receive free lodging and food of a modest or comfortable standard (depending on the quality of the establishment), as long as you perform each night. In addition, your performance makes you something of a local figure. When strangers recognize you in a town where you have performed, they typically take a liking to you.

 
Suggested Characteristics

Successful entertainers have to be able to capture and hold an audience’s attention, so they tend to have flamboyant or forceful personalities. They’re inclined toward the romantic and often cling to high-minded ideals about the practice of art and the appreciation of beauty.

D8 PERSONALITY TRAIT
1 I know a story relevant to almost every situation.
2 Whenever I come to a new place, I collect local rumors and spread gossip.
3 I’m a hopeless romantic, always searching for that “special someone.”
4 Nobody stays angry at me or around me for long, since I can defuse any amount of tension.
5 I love a good insult, even one directed at me.
6 I get bitter if I’m not the center of attention.
7 I’ll settle for nothing less than perfection.
8 I change my mood or my mind as quickly as I change key in a song.
D6 IDEAL
1 Beauty. When I perform, I make the world better than it was. (Good)
2 Tradition. The stories, legends, and songs of the past must never be forgotten, for they teach us who we are. (Lawful)
3 Creativity. The world is in need of new ideas and bold action. (Chaotic)
4 Greed. I’m only in it for the money and fame. (Evil)
5 People. I like seeing the smiles on people’s faces when I perform. That’s all that matters. (Neutral)
6 Honesty. Art should reflect the soul; it should come from within and reveal who we really are. (Any)
D6 BOND
1 My instrument is my most treasured possession, and it reminds me of someone I love.
2 Someone stole my precious instrument, and someday I’ll get it back.
3 I want to be famous, whatever it takes.
4 I idolize a hero of the old tales and measure my deeds against that person’s.
5 I will do anything to prove myself superior to my hated rival.
6 I would do anything for the other members of my old troupe.
D6 FLAW
1 I’ll do anything to win fame and renown.
2 I’m a sucker for a pretty face.
3 A scandal prevents me from ever going home again. That kind of trouble seems to follow me around.
4 I once satirized a noble who still wants my head. It was a mistake that I will likely repeat.
5 I have trouble keeping my true feelings hidden. My sharp tongue lands me in trouble.
6 Despite my best efforts, I am unreliable to my friends.

race.description:
Nomadic, lion-like humanoids who rarely interact with other peoples, having all they need in their shimmering homeland. 

Racial Traits
+2 Constitution, +1 Strength, Darkvision, Claws,  Hunter's Instincts, Daunting Roar.

definition.name: Ability Score Increase
definition.description: Your Constitution score increases by 2, and your Strength score increases by 1.

definition.name: Age
definition.description: Leonin mature and age at about the same rate as humans.

definition.name: Alignment
definition.description: Leonin tend toward good alignments. Leonin who are focused on the pride lean toward lawful good.

definition.name: Size
definition.description:
Leonin are typically over 6 feet tall, with some standing over 7 feet. Your size is Medium.

Here’s how to determine your height and weight randomly, starting with rolling a size modifier:

Size modifier = 2d10

Height = 5 feet + 6 inches + your size modifier in inches

Weight in pounds = 180 + (2d6 × your size modifier)

definition.name: Speed
definition.description: Your base walking speed is 35 feet.

definition.name: Darkvision
definition.description: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can’t discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.
definition.snippet: You can see in darkness (shades of gray) up to 60 ft.

definition.name: Claws
definition.description: Your claws are natural weapons, which you can use to make unarmed strikes. If you hit with them, you can deal slashing damage equal to 1d4 + your Strength modifier, instead of the bludgeoning damage normal for an unarmed strike.
definition.snippet: Unarmed strikes may deal 1d4{{modifier:str}} slashing damage on a hit.

definition.name: Hunter’s Instincts
definition.description: You have proficiency in one of the following skills of your choice: Athletics, Intimidation, Perception, or Survival.
definition.snippet: You have proficiency in one of the following skills of your choice: Athletics, Intimidation, Perception, or Survival.

definition.name: Daunting Roar
definition.description: As a bonus action, you can let out an especially menacing roar. Creatures of your choice within 10 feet of you that can hear you must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or become frightened of you until the end of your next turn. The DC of the save equals 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Constitution modifier. Once you use this trait, you can’t use it again until you finish a short or long rest.
definition.snippet: As a bonus action once per short rest, creatures of your choice within 10 ft. that can hear you must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw (DC{{savedc:con}}) or become frightened of you until the end of your next turn.

definition.name: Languages
definition.description: You can speak, read, and write Common and Leonin.
definition.snippet: You can speak, read, and write Common and Leonin.

notes.personalPossessions: a trophy from a defeated foe in the arena
notes.backstory:
something something fighting for sport as a "gladiator"

After being kicked out of the adventurers guild in Da'maar for causing one too many bar fights, Rex has set out to find fortune and fame in the new cool place Laguna.
notes.otherNotes:
Always rage, ADV on STR checks and resistance++

Use Reckless Attack (class feature) for advantage on my first attack of my turn

Use sentinel attack to punish enemies not interested in fighting you

Daunting roar is cool to make people frightened

traits.personalityTraits:
I’m painfully blunt which occasionally means rude.
I love a good insult, even one directed at me.
traits.ideals: Greed. I’m only in it for the money and fame. (Evil)
traits.bonds: I will do anything to prove myself superior to my hated rival.
traits.flaws: I can't say no to a physical challenge.

definition.name: Greatsword, +1
definition.description: You have a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls made with this magic weapon.

properties.name: Heavy
properties.description: Creatures that are Small or Tiny have disadvantage on attack rolls with heavy weapons. A heavy weapon's size and bulk make it too large for a Small or Tiny creature to use effectively.

properties.name: Two-Handed
properties.description: This weapon requires two hands when you attack with it.

definition.name: Shatterspike
definition.description: You have a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls you make with this magic weapon. If it hits an object, the hit is automatically a critical hit, and it can deal bludgeoning or slashing damage to the object (your choice). Further, damage from nonmagical sources can’t harm the weapon.

properties.name: Versatile
properties.description: This weapon can be used with one or two hands. A damage value in parentheses appears with the property--the damage when the weapon is used with two hands to make a melee attack.

definition.name: Glaive
definition.description: Proficiency with a glaive allows you to add your proficiency bonus to the attack roll for any attack you make with it.

properties.name: Heavy
properties.description: Creatures that are Small or Tiny have disadvantage on attack rolls with heavy weapons. A heavy weapon's size and bulk make it too large for a Small or Tiny creature to use effectively.

properties.name: Reach
properties.description: This weapon adds 5 feet to your reach when you attack with it, as well as when determining your reach for opportunity attacks with it.

properties.name: Two-Handed
properties.description: This weapon requires two hands when you attack with it.

definition.name: Handaxe
definition.description: Proficiency with a handaxe allows you to add your proficiency bonus to the attack roll for any attack you make with it.

properties.name: Light
properties.description: A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.

properties.name: Thrown
properties.description: If a weapon has the thrown property, you can throw the weapon to make a ranged attack. If the weapon is a melee weapon, you use the same ability modifier for that attack roll and damage roll that you would use for a melee attack with the weapon. For example, if you throw a handaxe, you use your Strength, but if you throw a dagger, you can use either your Strength or your Dexterity, since the dagger has the finesse property.

definition.name: Handaxe
definition.description: Proficiency with a handaxe allows you to add your proficiency bonus to the attack roll for any attack you make with it.

properties.name: Light
properties.description: A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.

properties.name: Thrown
properties.description: If a weapon has the thrown property, you can throw the weapon to make a ranged attack. If the weapon is a melee weapon, you use the same ability modifier for that attack roll and damage roll that you would use for a melee attack with the weapon. For example, if you throw a handaxe, you use your Strength, but if you throw a dagger, you can use either your Strength or your Dexterity, since the dagger has the finesse property.

definition.name: Javelin
definition.description: Proficiency with a javelin allows you to add your proficiency bonus to the attack roll for any attack you make with it.

properties.name: Thrown
properties.description: If a weapon has the thrown property, you can throw the weapon to make a ranged attack. If the weapon is a melee weapon, you use the same ability modifier for that attack roll and damage roll that you would use for a melee attack with the weapon. For example, if you throw a handaxe, you use your Strength, but if you throw a dagger, you can use either your Strength or your Dexterity, since the dagger has the finesse property.

definition.name: Maul
definition.description: Proficiency with a maul allows you to add your proficiency bonus to the attack roll for any attack you make with it.

properties.name: Heavy
properties.description: Creatures that are Small or Tiny have disadvantage on attack rolls with heavy weapons. A heavy weapon's size and bulk make it too large for a Small or Tiny creature to use effectively.

properties.name: Two-Handed
properties.description: This weapon requires two hands when you attack with it.

definition.name: Backpack
definition.description:
A backpack is a leather pack carried on the back, typically with straps to secure it. A backpack can hold 1 cubic foot/ 30 pounds of gear.

You can also strap items, such as a bedroll or a coil of rope, to the outside of a backpack.

definition.name: Clothes, Costume
definition.description: This set of clothes is fashioned after a particular costume, typically meant for entertaining.

definition.name: Potion of Healing (Greater)
definition.description: You regain 4d4 + 4 hit points when you drink this potion. The potion's red liquid glimmers when agitated.

definition.name: Bedroll
definition.description: You never know where you’re going to sleep, and a bedroll helps you get better sleep in a hayloft or on the cold ground. A bedroll consists of bedding and a blanket thin enough to be rolled up and tied. In an emergency, it can double as a stretcher.

definition.name: Mess Kit
definition.description: This tin box contains a cup and simple cutlery. The box clamps together, and one side can be used as a cooking pan and the other as a plate or shallow bowl.

definition.name: Potion of Healing
definition.description: A character who drinks the magical red fluid in this vial regains 2d4 + 2 hit points. Drinking or administering a potion takes an action.

definition.name: Rations (1 day)
definition.description: Rations consist of dry foods suitable for extended travel, including jerky, dried fruit, hardtack, and nuts.

definition.name: Rope, Hempen (50 feet)
definition.description: Rope, has 2 hit points and can be burst with a DC 17 Strength check.

definition.name: Tinderbox
definition.description: This small container holds flint, fire steel, and tinder (usually dry cloth soaked in light oil) used to kindle a fire. Using it to light a torch -- or anything else with abundant, exposed fuel -- takes an action. Lighting any other fire takes 1 minute.

definition.name: Torch
definition.description: A torch burns for 1 hour, providing bright light in a 20-foot radius and dim light for an additional 20 feet. If you make a melee attack with a burning torch and hit, it deals 1 fire damage.

definition.name: Waterskin
definition.description: A waterskin can hold 4 pints of liquid.

definition.name: Barbarian
definition.description:
A fierce warrior of primitive background who can enter a battle rage

Hit Die: d12
Primary Ability: Strength
Saves: Strength & Constitution
definition.equipmentDescription:
You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background:

  • (a) a greataxe or (b) any martial melee weapon
  • (a) two handaxes or (b) any simple weapon
  • An explorer’s pack and four javelins

classFeatures.name: Rage
classFeatures.description:
In battle, you fight with primal ferocity. On your turn, you can enter a rage as a bonus action.

While raging, you gain the following benefits if you aren’t wearing heavy armor:

  • You have advantage on Strength checks and Strength saving throws.
  • When you make a melee weapon attack using Strength, you gain a bonus to the damage roll that increases as you gain levels as a barbarian, as shown in the Rage Damage column of the Barbarian table.
  • You have resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage.

If you are able to cast spells, you can’t cast them or concentrate on them while raging.

Your rage lasts for 1 minute. It ends early if you are knocked unconscious or if your turn ends and you haven’t attacked a hostile creature since your last turn or taken damage since then. You can also end your rage on your turn as a bonus action.

Once you have raged the number of times shown for your barbarian level in the Rages column of the Barbarian table, you must finish a long rest before you can rage again.

classFeatures.name: Unarmored Defense
classFeatures.description: While you are not wearing any armor, your Armor Class equals 10 + your Dexterity modifier + your Constitution modifier. You can use a shield and still gain this benefit.

classFeatures.name: Reckless Attack
classFeatures.description: Starting at 2nd level, you can throw aside all concern for defense to attack with fierce desperation. When you make your first attack on your turn, you can decide to attack recklessly. Doing so gives you advantage on melee weapon attack rolls using Strength during this turn, but attack rolls against you have advantage until your next turn.

classFeatures.name: Danger Sense
classFeatures.description:
At 2nd level, you gain an uncanny sense of when things nearby aren’t as they should be, giving you an edge when you dodge away from danger.

You have advantage on Dexterity saving throws against effects that you can see, such as traps and spells. To gain this benefit, you can’t be blinded, deafened, or incapacitated.

classFeatures.name: Primal Path
classFeatures.description: At 3rd level, you choose a path that shapes the nature of your rage. The Path of the Berserker is detailed at the end of the class description, and additional primal paths are available in other sources. Your choice grants you features at 3rd level and again at 6th, 10th, and 14th levels.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
classFeatures.description:
When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
classFeatures.description:
When you reach 8th level, and again at 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
classFeatures.description:
When you reach 12th level, and again at 16th and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
classFeatures.description:
When you reach 16th level, and again at 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
classFeatures.description:
When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

classFeatures.name: Extra Attack
classFeatures.description: Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

classFeatures.name: Fast Movement
classFeatures.description: Starting at 5th level, your speed increases by 10 feet while you aren’t wearing heavy armor.

classFeatures.name: Feral Instinct
classFeatures.description:
By 7th level, your instincts are so honed that you have advantage on initiative rolls.

Additionally, if you are surprised at the beginning of combat and aren’t incapacitated, you can act normally on your first turn, but only if you enter your rage before doing anything else on that turn.

classFeatures.name: Brutal Critical
classFeatures.description:
Beginning at 9th level, you can roll one additional weapon damage die when determining the extra damage for a critical hit with a melee attack.

This increases to two additional dice at 13th level and three additional dice at 17th level.

classFeatures.name: Brutal Critical
classFeatures.description:
At 13th level, you can roll two additional weapon damage dice when determining the extra damage for a critical hit with a melee attack.

This increases to three additional dice at 17th level.

classFeatures.name: Brutal Critical
classFeatures.description: At 17th level, you can roll three additional weapon damage dice when determining the extra damage for a critical hit with a melee attack.

classFeatures.name: Relentless Rage
classFeatures.description:
Starting at 11th level, your rage can keep you fighting despite grievous wounds. If you drop to 0 hit points while you’re raging and don’t die outright, you can make a DC 10 Constitution saving throw. If you succeed, you drop to 1 hit point instead.

Each time you use this feature after the first, the DC increases by 5. When you finish a short or long rest, the DC resets to 10.

classFeatures.name: Persistent Rage
classFeatures.description: Beginning at 15th level, your rage is so fierce that it ends early only if you fall unconscious or if you choose to end it.

classFeatures.name: Indomitable Might
classFeatures.description: Beginning at 18th level, if your total for a Strength check is less than your Strength score, you can use that score in place of the total.

classFeatures.name: Primal Champion
classFeatures.description: At 20th level, you embody the power of the wilds. Your Strength and Constitution scores increase by 4. Your maximum for those scores is now 24.

classFeatures.name: Proficiencies
classFeatures.description:
Armor: Light armor, medium armor, shields
Weapons: Simple weapons, martial weapons
Tools: None
Saving Throws: Strength, Constitution
Skills: Choose two from Animal Handling, Athletics, Intimidation, Nature, Perception, and Survival

classFeatures.name: Hit Points
classFeatures.description:
Hit Dice: 1d12 per barbarian level
Hit Points at 1st Level: 12 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d12 (or 7) + your Constitution modifier per barbarian level after 1st

subclassDefinition.name: Path of the Totem Warrior
subclassDefinition.description:
The Path of the Totem Warrior is a spiritual journey, as the barbarian accepts a spirit animal as guide, protector, and inspiration. In battle, your totem spirit fills you with supernatural might, adding magical fuel to your barbarian rage.

Most barbarian tribes consider a totem animal to be kin to a particular clan. In such cases, it is unusual for an individual to have more than one totem animal spirit, though exceptions exist.

classFeatures.name: Spirit Seeker
classFeatures.description: Yours is a path that seeks attunement with the natural world, giving you a kinship with beasts. At 3rd level when you adopt this path, you gain the ability to cast the beast sense and speak with animals spells, but only as rituals, as described in the Spellcasting section.

classFeatures.name: Totem Spirit
classFeatures.description:
At 3rd level, when you adopt this path, you choose a totem spirit and gain its feature. You must make or acquire a physical totem object — an amulet or similar adornment — that incorporates fur or feathers, claws, teeth, or bones of the totem animal. At your option, you also gain minor physical attributes that are reminiscent of your totem spirit. For example, if you have a bear totem spirit, you might be unusually hairy and thick-skinned, or if your totem is the eagle, your eyes turn bright yellow.

Your totem animal might be an animal related to those listed here but more appropriate to your homeland. For example, you could choose a hawk or vulture in place of an eagle.

classFeatures.name: Aspect of the Beast
classFeatures.description: At 6th level, you gain a magical benefit based on the totem animal of your choice. You can choose the same animal you selected at 3rd level or a different one.

classFeatures.name: Spirit Walker
classFeatures.description: At 10th level, you can cast the commune with nature spell, but only as a ritual. When you do so, a spiritual version of one of the animals you chose for Totem Spirit or Aspect of the Beast appears to you to convey the information you seek.

classFeatures.name: Totemic Attunement
classFeatures.description: At 14th level, you gain a magical benefit based on a totem animal of your choice. You can choose the same animal you selected previously or a different one.

classFeatures.name: Rage
classFeatures.description:
In battle, you fight with primal ferocity. On your turn, you can enter a rage as a bonus action.

While raging, you gain the following benefits if you aren’t wearing heavy armor:

  • You have advantage on Strength checks and Strength saving throws.
  • When you make a melee weapon attack using Strength, you gain a bonus to the damage roll that increases as you gain levels as a barbarian, as shown in the Rage Damage column of the Barbarian table.
  • You have resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage.

If you are able to cast spells, you can’t cast them or concentrate on them while raging.

Your rage lasts for 1 minute. It ends early if you are knocked unconscious or if your turn ends and you haven’t attacked a hostile creature since your last turn or taken damage since then. You can also end your rage on your turn as a bonus action.

Once you have raged the number of times shown for your barbarian level in the Rages column of the Barbarian table, you must finish a long rest before you can rage again.

classFeatures.name: Unarmored Defense
classFeatures.description: While you are not wearing any armor, your Armor Class equals 10 + your Dexterity modifier + your Constitution modifier. You can use a shield and still gain this benefit.

classFeatures.name: Reckless Attack
classFeatures.description: Starting at 2nd level, you can throw aside all concern for defense to attack with fierce desperation. When you make your first attack on your turn, you can decide to attack recklessly. Doing so gives you advantage on melee weapon attack rolls using Strength during this turn, but attack rolls against you have advantage until your next turn.

classFeatures.name: Danger Sense
classFeatures.description:
At 2nd level, you gain an uncanny sense of when things nearby aren’t as they should be, giving you an edge when you dodge away from danger.

You have advantage on Dexterity saving throws against effects that you can see, such as traps and spells. To gain this benefit, you can’t be blinded, deafened, or incapacitated.

classFeatures.name: Primal Path
classFeatures.description: At 3rd level, you choose a path that shapes the nature of your rage. The Path of the Berserker is detailed at the end of the class description, and additional primal paths are available in other sources. Your choice grants you features at 3rd level and again at 6th, 10th, and 14th levels.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
classFeatures.description:
When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

By 7th level, your instincts are so honed that you have advantage on initiative rolls.

Additionally, if you are surprised at the beginning of combat and aren’t incapacitated, you can act normally on your first turn, but only if you enter your rage before doing anything else on that turn.

classFeatures.name: Brutal Critical
classFeatures.description:
Beginning at 9th level, you can roll one additional weapon damage die when determining the extra damage for a critical hit with a melee attack.

This increases to two additional dice at 13th level and three additional dice at 17th level.

classFeatures.name: Brutal Critical
classFeatures.description:
At 13th level, you can roll two additional weapon damage dice when determining the extra damage for a critical hit with a melee attack.

This increases to three additional dice at 17th level.

classFeatures.name: Brutal Critical
classFeatures.description: At 17th level, you can roll three additional weapon damage dice when determining the extra damage for a critical hit with a melee attack.

classFeatures.name: Relentless Rage
classFeatures.description:
Starting at 11th level, your rage can keep you fighting despite grievous wounds. If you drop to 0 hit points while you’re raging and don’t die outright, you can make a DC 10 Constitution saving throw. If you succeed, you drop to 1 hit point instead.

Each time you use this feature after the first, the DC increases by 5. When you finish a short or long rest, the DC resets to 10.

classFeatures.name: Persistent Rage
classFeatures.description: Beginning at 15th level, your rage is so fierce that it ends early only if you fall unconscious or if you choose to end it.

classFeatures.name: Indomitable Might
classFeatures.description: Beginning at 18th level, if your total for a Strength check is less than your Strength score, you can use that score in place of the total.

classFeatures.name: Primal Champion
classFeatures.description: At 20th level, you embody the power of the wilds. Your Strength and Constitution scores increase by 4. Your maximum for those scores is now 24.

classFeatures.name: Proficiencies
classFeatures.description:
Armor: Light armor, medium armor, shields
Weapons: Simple weapons, martial weapons
Tools: None
Saving Throws: Strength, Constitution
Skills: Choose two from Animal Handling, Athletics, Intimidation, Nature, Perception, and Survival

classFeatures.name: Hit Points
classFeatures.description:
Hit Dice: 1d12 per barbarian level
Hit Points at 1st Level: 12 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d12 (or 7) + your Constitution modifier per barbarian level after 1st

definition.name: Spirit Seeker
definition.description: Yours is a path that seeks attunement with the natural world, giving you a kinship with beasts. At 3rd level when you adopt this path, you gain the ability to cast the beast sense and speak with animals spells, but only as rituals, as described in the Spellcasting section.
definition.snippet: You can cast beast sense and speak with animals as rituals.

definition.name: Totem Spirit
definition.description:
At 3rd level, when you adopt this path, you choose a totem spirit and gain its feature. You must make or acquire a physical totem object — an amulet or similar adornment — that incorporates fur or feathers, claws, teeth, or bones of the totem animal. At your option, you also gain minor physical attributes that are reminiscent of your totem spirit. For example, if you have a bear totem spirit, you might be unusually hairy and thick-skinned, or if your totem is the eagle, your eyes turn bright yellow.

Your totem animal might be an animal related to those listed here but more appropriate to your homeland. For example, you could choose a hawk or vulture in place of an eagle.
definition.snippet: You have adopted a totem spirit.

definition.name: Aspect of the Beast
definition.description: At 6th level, you gain a magical benefit based on the totem animal of your choice. You can choose the same animal you selected at 3rd level or a different one.
definition.snippet: You gain a magical benefit based on the totem animal of your choice.

definition.name: Spirit Walker
definition.description: At 10th level, you can cast the commune with nature spell, but only as a ritual. When you do so, a spiritual version of one of the animals you chose for Totem Spirit or Aspect of the Beast appears to you to convey the information you seek.
definition.snippet: You can cast the commune with nature spell as a ritual.

definition.name: Totemic Attunement
definition.description: At 14th level, you gain a magical benefit based on a totem animal of your choice. You can choose the same animal you selected previously or a different one.
definition.snippet: You gain an additional magical benefit based on a totem animal of your choice.

definition.name: Rage
definition.description:
In battle, you fight with primal ferocity. On your turn, you can enter a rage as a bonus action.

While raging, you gain the following benefits if you aren’t wearing heavy armor:

  • You have advantage on Strength checks and Strength saving throws.
  • When you make a melee weapon attack using Strength, you gain a bonus to the damage roll that increases as you gain levels as a barbarian, as shown in the Rage Damage column of the Barbarian table.
  • You have resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage.

If you are able to cast spells, you can’t cast them or concentrate on them while raging.

Your rage lasts for 1 minute. It ends early if you are knocked unconscious or if your turn ends and you haven’t attacked a hostile creature since your last turn or taken damage since then. You can also end your rage on your turn as a bonus action.

Once you have raged the number of times shown for your barbarian level in the Rages column of the Barbarian table, you must finish a long rest before you can rage again.
definition.snippet:
As a bonus action enter a rage for up to 1 minute (10 rounds). 

You gain advantage on STR checks and saving throws (not attacks), {{scalevalue#signed}} melee damage with STR weapons, resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, slashing damage. You can't cast or concentrate on spells while raging.

Your rage ends early if you are knocked unconscious or if your turn ends and you haven’t attacked a hostile creature since your last turn or taken damage since then. You can also end your rage as a bonus action.

definition.name: Unarmored Defense
definition.description: While you are not wearing any armor, your Armor Class equals 10 + your Dexterity modifier + your Constitution modifier. You can use a shield and still gain this benefit.
definition.snippet: While not wearing armor, your AC equals 10 + DEX modifier + CON modifier + any shield bonus.
definition.multiClassDescription:
This feature could be affected by multiclassing. See the Multiclassing rules for more information.

While you are not wearing any armor, your Armor Class equals 10 + your Dexterity modifier + your Constitution modifier. You can use a shield and still gain this benefit.

definition.name: Reckless Attack
definition.description: Starting at 2nd level, you can throw aside all concern for defense to attack with fierce desperation. When you make your first attack on your turn, you can decide to attack recklessly. Doing so gives you advantage on melee weapon attack rolls using Strength during this turn, but attack rolls against you have advantage until your next turn.
definition.snippet: When you make your first attack on your turn, you can decide to attack recklessly, giving you advantage on melee weapon attack rolls using STR during this turn, but attack rolls against you have advantage until your next turn.

definition.name: Danger Sense
definition.description:
At 2nd level, you gain an uncanny sense of when things nearby aren’t as they should be, giving you an edge when you dodge away from danger.

You have advantage on Dexterity saving throws against effects that you can see, such as traps and spells. To gain this benefit, you can’t be blinded, deafened, or incapacitated.
definition.snippet: You have advantage on DEX saving throws against effects that you can see while not blinded, deafened, or incapacitated.

definition.name: Primal Path
definition.description: At 3rd level, you choose a path that shapes the nature of your rage. The Path of the Berserker is detailed at the end of the class description, and additional primal paths are available in other sources. Your choice grants you features at 3rd level and again at 6th, 10th, and 14th levels.

definition.name: Ability Score Improvement
definition.description:
When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

definition.name: Ability Score Improvement
definition.description:
When you reach 8th level, and again at 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

definition.name: Ability Score Improvement
definition.description:
When you reach 12th level, and again at 16th and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

definition.name: Ability Score Improvement
definition.description:
When you reach 16th level, and again at 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

definition.name: Ability Score Improvement
definition.description:
When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

definition.name: Extra Attack
definition.description: Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.
definition.snippet: You can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.
definition.multiClassDescription:
This feature could be affected by multiclassing. See the Multiclassing rules for more information.

Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

definition.name: Fast Movement
definition.description: Starting at 5th level, your speed increases by 10 feet while you aren’t wearing heavy armor.
definition.snippet: Your speed increases by 10 ft. while you aren't wearing heavy armor.

definition.name: Feral Instinct
definition.description:
By 7th level, your instincts are so honed that you have advantage on initiative rolls.

Additionally, if you are surprised at the beginning of combat and aren’t incapacitated, you can act normally on your first turn, but only if you enter your rage before doing anything else on that turn.
definition.snippet: You have advantage on initiative rolls. Also, if you are surprised at the beginning of combat but not incapacitated, you can act normally on your first turn if you enter a rage before doing anything else.

definition.name: Brutal Critical
definition.description:
Beginning at 9th level, you can roll one additional weapon damage die when determining the extra damage for a critical hit with a melee attack.

This increases to two additional dice at 13th level and three additional dice at 17th level.
definition.snippet: You can roll one additional weapon damage die when determining the extra damage for a critical hit with a melee attack.

definition.name: Brutal Critical
definition.description:
At 13th level, you can roll two additional weapon damage dice when determining the extra damage for a critical hit with a melee attack.

This increases to three additional dice at 17th level.
definition.snippet: You can roll two additional weapon damage dice when determining the extra damage for a critical hit with a melee attack.

definition.name: Brutal Critical
definition.description: At 17th level, you can roll three additional weapon damage dice when determining the extra damage for a critical hit with a melee attack.
definition.snippet: You can roll three additional weapon damage dice when determining the extra damage for a critical hit with a melee attack.

definition.name: Relentless Rage
definition.description:
Starting at 11th level, your rage can keep you fighting despite grievous wounds. If you drop to 0 hit points while you’re raging and don’t die outright, you can make a DC 10 Constitution saving throw. If you succeed, you drop to 1 hit point instead.

Each time you use this feature after the first, the DC increases by 5. When you finish a short or long rest, the DC resets to 10.
definition.snippet:
If you drop to 0 hit points while you’re raging and don’t die, you can make a DC 10 CON saving throw. If you succeed, you drop to 1 hit point instead. 

The DC increase by 5 each time you use this after the first, resetting to 10 after a short or long rest.

definition.name: Persistent Rage
definition.description: Beginning at 15th level, your rage is so fierce that it ends early only if you fall unconscious or if you choose to end it.
definition.snippet: Your rage ends early only if you fall unconscious or if you choose to end it.

definition.name: Indomitable Might
definition.description: Beginning at 18th level, if your total for a Strength check is less than your Strength score, you can use that score in place of the total.
definition.snippet: If your total for a Strength check is less than your Strength score, you can use that score in place of the total.

definition.name: Primal Champion
definition.description: At 20th level, you embody the power of the wilds. Your Strength and Constitution scores increase by 4. Your maximum for those scores is now 24.
definition.snippet: Your Strength and Constitution scores increase by 4. Your maximum for those scores is now 24.

definition.name: Proficiencies
definition.description:
Armor: Light armor, medium armor, shields
Weapons: Simple weapons, martial weapons
Tools: None
Saving Throws: Strength, Constitution
Skills: Choose two from Animal Handling, Athletics, Intimidation, Nature, Perception, and Survival

definition.name: Hit Points
definition.description:
Hit Dice: 1d12 per barbarian level
Hit Points at 1st Level: 12 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d12 (or 7) + your Constitution modifier per barbarian level after 1st

definition.name: Great Weapon Master
definition.description:
You've learned to put the weight of a weapon to your advantage, letting its momentum empower your strikes. You gain the following benefits:

  • On your turn, when you score a critical hit with a melee weapon or reduce a creature to 0 hit points with one, you can make one melee weapon attack as a bonus action.
  • Before you make a melee attack with a heavy weapon that you are proficient with, you can choose to take a -5 penalty to the attack roll. If the attack hits, you add +10 to the attack's damage.
definition.snippet: On your turn, when you score a critical hit with a melee weapon or reduce a creature to 0 HP with one, you can make one melee weapon attack as a bonus action. Before you make a melee attack with a heavy weapon that you are proficient with, you can choose to take a -5 penalty to the attack roll to add +10 to the attack's damage.

definition.name: Sentinel
definition.description:
You have mastered techniques to take advantage of every drop in any enemy's guard, gaining the following benefits:

  • When you hit a creature with an opportunity attack, the creature's speed becomes 0 for the rest of the turn.
  • Creatures provoke opportunity attacks from you even if they take the Disengage action before leaving your reach.
  • When a creature within 5 feet of you makes an attack against a target other than you (and that target doesn't have this feat), you can use your reaction to make a melee weapon attack against the attacking creature.
definition.snippet: When you hit a creature with an opportunity attack, the creature's speed becomes 0 for the rest of the turn. Creatures provoke opportunity attacks from you even if they take the Disengage action. When a creature within 5 ft. of you makes an attack against a target other than you, you can use your reaction to make a melee weapon attack against the attacking creature.

definition.name: Beast Sense
definition.description: You touch a willing beast. For the duration of the spell, you can use your action to see through the beast’s eyes and hear what it hears, and continue to do so until you use your action to return to your normal senses. While perceiving through the beast’s senses, you gain the benefits of any special senses possessed by that creature, though you are blinded and deafened to your own surroundings.

definition.name: Speak with Animals
definition.description: You gain the ability to comprehend and verbally communicate with beasts for the duration. The knowledge and awareness of many beasts is limited by their intelligence, but at minimum, beasts can give you information about nearby locations and monsters, including whatever they can perceive or have perceived within the past day. You might be able to persuade a beast to perform a small favor for you, at the GM's discretion.

definition.name: Bear
definition.description: While raging, you have resistance to all damage except psychic damage. The spirit of the bear makes you tough enough to stand up to any punishment.
definition.snippet: While raging, you have resistance to all damage except psychic damage.

definition.name: Tiger
definition.description: You gain proficiency in two skills from the following list: Athletics, Acrobatics, Stealth, and Survival. The cat spirit hones your survival instincts.
definition.snippet: You gain proficiency in two skills from the following list: Athletics, Acrobatics, Stealth, and Survival.

options.label: Eagle
options.description: While you’re raging, other creatures have disadvantage on opportunity attack rolls against you, and you can use the Dash action as a bonus action on your turn. The spirit of the eagle makes you into a predator who can weave through the fray with ease.

options.label: Wolf
options.description: While you’re raging, your friends have advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature within 5 feet of you that is hostile to you. The spirit of the wolf makes you a leader of hunters.

options.label: Elk
options.description: While you are raging and aren't wearing heavy armor, your walking speed increases by 15 feet. The spirit of the elk makes you extraordinarily swift.

options.label: Tiger
options.description: While raging, you can add 10 feet to your long jump distance and 3 feet to your high jump distance. The spirit of the tiger empowers your leaps.

options.label: Bear
options.description: While raging, you have resistance to all damage except psychic damage. The spirit of the bear makes you tough enough to stand up to any punishment.

options.label: Bear
options.description: You gain the might of a bear. Your carrying capacity (including maximum load and maximum lift) is doubled, and you have advantage on Strength checks made to push, pull, lift, or break objects.

options.label: Eagle
options.description: You gain the eyesight of an eagle. You can see up to 1 mile away with no difficulty, able to discern even fine details as though looking at something no more than 100 feet away from you. Additionally, dim light doesn’t impose disadvantage on your Wisdom (Perception) checks.

options.label: Wolf
options.description: You gain the hunting sensibilities of a wolf. You can track other creatures while traveling at a fast pace, and you can move stealthily while traveling at a normal pace (see “Adventuring,” for rules on travel pace).

options.label: Elk
options.description: Whether mounted or on foot, your travel pace is doubled, as is the travel pace of up to ten companions while they’re within 60 feet of you and you’re not incapacitated (see “Adventuring,” for rules on travel pace). The elk spirit helps you roam far and fast.

options.label: Tiger
options.description: You gain proficiency in two skills from the following list: Athletics, Acrobatics, Stealth, and Survival. The cat spirit hones your survival instincts.

race.name: Claws
race.description: Your claws are natural weapons, which you can use to make unarmed strikes. If you hit with them, you can deal slashing damage equal to 1d4 + your Strength modifier, instead of the bludgeoning damage normal for an unarmed strike.
race.snippet: Unarmed strikes may deal 1d4{{modifier:str}} slashing damage on a hit.

race.name: Daunting Roar
race.description: As a bonus action, you can let out an especially menacing roar. Creatures of your choice within 10 feet of you that can hear you must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or become [condition]frightened[/condition] of you until the end of your next turn. The DC of the save equals 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Constitution modifier. Once you use this trait, you can’t use it again until you finish a short or long rest.
race.snippet: As a bonus action once per short rest, creatures of your choice within 10 ft. that can hear you must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw (DC{{savedc:con}}) or become frightened of you until the end of your next turn.
race.saveFailDescription: Become [condition]frightened[/condition] of you until the end of your next turn.

class.name: Rage
class.description:
In battle, you fight with primal ferocity. On your turn, you can enter a rage as a bonus action.

While raging, you gain the following benefits if you aren’t wearing heavy armor:

  • You have advantage on Strength checks and Strength saving throws.
  • When you make a melee weapon attack using Strength, you gain a bonus to the damage roll that increases as you gain levels as a barbarian, as shown in the Rage Damage column of the Barbarian table.
  • You have resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage.

If you are able to cast spells, you can’t cast them or concentrate on them while raging.

Your rage lasts for 1 minute. It ends early if you are knocked [condition]unconscious[/condition] or if your turn ends and you haven’t attacked a hostile creature since your last turn or taken damage since then. You can also end your rage on your turn as a bonus action.

Once you have raged the number of times shown for your barbarian level in the Rages column of the Barbarian table, you must finish a long rest before you can rage again.
class.snippet:
As a bonus action enter a rage for up to 1 minute (10 rounds). 

You gain advantage on STR checks and saving throws (not attacks), {{scalevalue#signed}} melee damage with STR weapons, resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, slashing damage. You can't cast or concentrate on spells while raging.

Your rage ends early if you are knocked unconscious or if your turn ends and you haven’t attacked a hostile creature since your last turn or taken damage since then. You can also end your rage as a bonus action.

class.name: Instinctive Pounce
class.description:
7th-level barbarian feature
As part of the bonus action you take to enter your rage, you can move up to half your speed.
class.snippet: As part of the bonus action you take to enter your rage, you can move up to half your speed.

feat.name: Great Weapon Master Attack
feat.snippet: On your turn, when you score a critical hit with a melee weapon or reduce a creature to 0 HP with one, you can make one melee weapon attack as a bonus action.

feat.name: Sentinel Attack
feat.snippet: When a creature within 5 ft. of you makes an attack against a target other than you, you can use your reaction to make a melee weapon attack against the attacking creature.

class.restriction: against effects that you can see while not blinded, deafened, or incapacitated
while you aren’t wearing heavy armor
